Granular schema/type validation: tests largely cover missing fields and max length, but not exhaustive data-type or value-range checks for each CustomField attribute (e.g., allowed objectType values, precise objectId format beyond UUID, numeric/date validation).
recommendations: Add tests for Content-Type: send requests without Content-Type or with wrong content-type and expect 400 (or appropriate error).
Add negative tests for X-Killbill-CreatedBy value (empty string, excessively long, invalid characters) to ensure header validation and clear error messages.

Add explicit tests to assert PUT semantics: verify whether a partial array replaces or merges existing custom fields; add a transactional test where one failing item should cause the whole update to roll back (or document expected behavior and test accordingly).
Add concurrency tests that target the same account from multiple clients simultaneously to detect race conditions and verify conflict resolution/locking behavior.
Add tests for invalid/expired authentication tokens to ensure consistent 401/403 behavior and messaging.
Add idempotency/duplicate-submission tests: repeat the same PUT and validate stable state and absence of duplicate side effects.
Add rate-limiting tests (flood/burst) to validate throttling and 429 responses if applicable.
Simulate generic 500 Internal Server Error (e.g., DB failure) to verify 500 responses and that system behavior/logging is correct.
Assert response headers and error body schema in tests (Content-Type, error codes, structured error details) and reconcile the spec (204 vs "Produces: application/json").
Expand schema tests to cover precise data types and constraints for each CustomField property (allowed values, formats, min/max lengths) and include negative cases for each constraint.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/catalog - Retrieve the catalog as JSON

covered: Valid requests: TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04 and TC16 exercise successful retrieval (latest catalog, requestedDate, accountId, and combinations) and assert 200 + JSON array response.
Empty / Not found responses: TC05 and TC06 cover absence of any catalog and no-catalog-for-requestedDate -> 404 handling.
Query parameter validation: TC07 (invalid requestedDate), TC08 (invalid accountId), TC11 (unsupported params ignored), TC17 (min/max date) cover many parameter validation and combination scenarios.
Authorization: TC09 and TC10 verify missing and invalid authentication tokens (401 responses).
Response format & schema: TC01 and TC23 assert Content-Type application/json and TC23 explicitly requires validation against the API schema.
Error scenarios: TC07, TC08, TC05, TC06, TC09, TC10, TC14, TC15 and TC22 cover a broad set of error responses (400/422, 401, 404, 503, 504).
Performance & concurrency: TC12 and TC13 exercise large dataset performance and concurrent requests.
Large payload / truncation: TC18 ensures very large responses are returned and not truncated.
Security: TC15 checks handling of a SQL-injection-like payload in query parameters.
Stability & regression: TC19, TC20, TC21 cover regression, backward-compatibility and retry-after-transient-error recovery scenarios.
gaps: Pagination: No tests address pagination (page/limit, offsets, pagination metadata or headers) or how very large result sets should be paged; the guidelines explicitly call this out.
Caching behavior: No tests assert caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or conditional requests (If-None-Match -> 304).
Rate limiting / throttling: TC13 exercises concurrency but there are no tests that intentionally exceed rate limits to verify 429/Retry-After behavior.
500 Internal Server Error handling: No scenario simulates a server/DB crash to verify 500 and consistent error reporting.
403 Forbidden / fine-grained authorization: Tests cover missing/invalid auth (401) but not valid auth with insufficient privileges (403), e.g., access to another tenant/account.
Method restrictions: No tests assert that unsupported HTTP methods (POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE) return proper 405 responses.
Error response consistency & headers: Error scenarios do not consistently assert error response Content-Type, a standard error schema (errorCode/message), or presence of helpful headers.
Content negotiation: No tests for Accept header handling or 406 Not Acceptable responses when client cannot accept application/json.
Date-time edge cases & timezone handling: Tests do not explicitly cover timezone offsets, DST transitions, or ambiguous date-time inputs (beyond invalid format).

Field-level schema validation coverage is limited: although TC23 requests schema validation, most success scenarios only assert "JSON array of Catalog objects" without checking required fields, types, or nested object correctness for each Catalog instance.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: if the API supports pagination, add tests for page/limit parameters, verify pagination metadata (total/pages), and ensure correctness when iterating pages; if it does not support pagination, document and test how very large responses are handled (streaming, timeouts).

Add caching tests: assert ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified headers; add conditional requests (If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since) and verify 304 Not Modified behavior and that account/requestedDate variations produce separate cache keys when appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests: craft burst requests to trigger throttling and assert 429 responses and Retry-After headers; include sustained high-rate tests to validate graceful degradation.
Simulate server failures: add tests that induce DB/service errors to verify 500 Internal Server Error behavior and ensure error responses follow a consistent JSON error schema and status codes.
Add authorization edge cases: test 403 scenarios (valid token but insufficient permissions or cross-tenant access), and test account-scoped access rules (account exists but user not authorized).
Test unsupported HTTP methods: ensure POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE on this endpoint return 405 with appropriate Allow header.
Standardize error response assertions: require Content-Type application/json for errors and assert a canonical error schema (fields like code, message, details) across scenarios.
Expand date-time edge-case coverage: add tests for timezone offsets, leap-days, DST boundaries, and very large/small date-time values to validate requestedDate handling.

Increase schema assertions: extend TC23 into multiple tests that validate required fields, types, and nested structures in each Catalog object (plans, products, prices), and include negative tests for missing mandatory fields.
Add tenant/account edge-case tests: accountId exists but has no tenant-specific catalog, account is deleted/soft-deleted, account belongs to different tenant — verify correct 404/403 behavior.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/payments - Trigger a payment (authorization, purchase or credit)

covered: Primary success flows: successful payment creation (201) with Payment JSON body, Location header and application/json Content-Type are explicitly tested (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC16, TC18, TC24).
Header handling: required X-Killbill-CreatedBy presence and missing-header negative case (TC01/TC02/TC06); optional X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment exercised (TC01).

Query parameters: paymentMethodId default behavior and explicit selection (TC01, TC02, TC24); multiple controlPluginName and pluginProperty values covered (TC03); control-plugin abort behavior covered (TC11).

Error-code mapping: the suite covers the acceptance error scenarios with tests for 400 (invalid/malformed input TC04/TC07/TC09), 402 (declined TC10), 404 (account not found TC08), 422 (aborted by control plugin TC11), 502/503/504 (gateway/dependency/timeouts TC12/TC13/TC14).
Validation and payload edge cases: malformed body (TC09), unsupported currency (TC19), large payloads (TC05), extra unexpected parameters (TC15), min/max amount boundaries (TC16/TC17).
Security and auth: authentication negative case covered (TC20) and malicious input validation tested (TC21).

Resilience, concurrency and performance: concurrent requests and duplicate/inconsistency concerns (TC22), dependent-service degradation (TC23), and performance/stress scenarios (TC26-TC28) are present.
Background / setup: tests include preconditions (API reachable, DB seeded with accounts/payment methods, plugins configured, auth token available), so environment expectations are documented.
Accessibility / docs: API documentation and error-message accessibility scenarios included (TC29, TC30).
gaps: Field-level validation gaps: no explicit tests for missing required PaymentTransaction fields (amount, currency, transactionType) or precise invalid-data-type checks and precision/scale validation for amount.
Transaction-type coverage: no explicit scenarios that exercise and assert behaviors per transactionType (authorization vs purchase vs credit) and their different lifecycle outcomes.

paymentMethodId negatives: no explicit tests for invalid-format paymentMethodId or a non-existent paymentMethodId (distinct from account-not-found) and for payment methods in bad states (expired, revoked, disabled).
Content-Type request validation: missing/incorrect request Content-Type (e.g., absent or non-application/json) and expected 415 behavior is not tested.
Duplicate submission / idempotency: absence of explicit duplicate submission tests or idempotency-key behavior; TC22 concurrency does not guarantee coverage of duplicate-idempotency semantics.
Server/internal errors: no explicit simulation of 500 Internal Server Error or database failure modes to validate server-error handling and meaningful 5xx payloads.
Authorization granularity: no 403 Forbidden tests for authenticated but unauthorized users (roles/scopes).
Plugin property negatives: no tests for invalid pluginProperty formats, mismatched pluginName/pluginProperty mapping, or malformed plugin arrays.
Error-response schema consistency: tests assert error presence but do not validate a consistent machine-readable error schema (fields like code, message, details) across error cases.
Rate limiting/throttling: no tests for rate limits or throttling behavior under high request rates (distinct from performance tests).
Location header verification: tests check Location exists but do not assert its exact format or perform a subsequent GET to verify the created resource is retrievable.
TC25 (backward compatibility) is vague/under-specified and should be clarified or replaced with a concrete compatibility test against an older API version.
recommendations: Add field-level negative tests for missing required fields (amount, currency, transactionType) and for invalid types/values (non-numeric amount, excessive precision, negative/zero amounts).
Add explicit scenarios per transactionType (authorization, purchase, credit) to assert their distinct outcomes and any subsequent lifecycle behavior (e.g., authorization vs immediate capture).
Add tests for invalid and non-existent paymentMethodId values and for payment methods in bad states (expired, revoked, disabled) to ensure correct 400/404/409 handling as appropriate.
Add request Content-Type validation tests (missing or incorrect Content-Type) and expect proper error (415 or documented behavior).

Implement duplicate-submission/idempotency tests: if idempotency-key is supported, validate idempotent behavior; otherwise verify how repeated identical requests are handled (duplicate creation vs rejection).
Simulate server/internal failures (DB errors, unexpected exceptions) to validate 500 responses and that error payloads are informative and consistent.
Add 403 Forbidden tests to cover authorization/role-based access control cases (authenticated but not permitted).
Add negative tests for pluginProperty shapes and mismatched controlPluginName/pluginProperty combinations to ensure plugin-parameter validation.
Standardize and assert error-response schema across all error cases (code, message, details) and include automated checks for machine-readable error structure and accessibility.
Add rate-limiting and throttling tests (burst requests beyond quota) and confirm the system returns appropriate 429 or documented behavior and protects resources.
Verify Location header contents (format and contained resource ID) and perform a GET of the returned URL to ensure the created Payment resource exists and matches the POST response.
Clarify and fix TC25: implement a concrete backward-compatibility test against a specific older API version or remove if not applicable.

Prioritize additions: high — field-level validation, per-transactionType tests, paymentMethodId negatives, idempotency/duplicate tests, Content-Type checks, 500 simulation; medium — pluginProperty negatives, 403 tests, error-schema assertions; low — additional performance thresholds, extended accessibility checks, and extra edge cases (very long headers).

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/bundles/{bundleId}/block - Block a bundle

covered: Valid payload / success flows: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC13-15) exercise successful creation with required and optional fields and assert HTTP 201 and response JSON array.
Request-body validation: Malformed body, missing body and invalid field formats are tested (TC08, TC10, TC11) covering common negative payload cases.
Path parameter validation and not-found handling: Invalid UUID format and non-existent bundle scenarios are covered (TC06, TC07, TC05) with expected 400/404 responses.
Header handling: Required header presence and missing-header cases covered (TC01, TC09); optional headers X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment covered (TC02, TC03).
Query-parameter handling: requestedDate and pluginProperty presence and format validated in positive and negative cases (TC02, TC04, TC11).
Response content / schema checks: Tests assert response is JSON array of BlockingState objects and check expected fields/effective date/plugin properties (TC01, TC02).
Security: Injection and XSS attempts are explicitly tested (TC19, TC20).
Concurrency and resilience: Concurrent requests and retry on transient network errors covered (TC21, TC22).
Boundary and size tests: Max/min field-length and large payload stress are present (TC13, TC14, TC16).
Integration / service errors: Service unavailability and dependent-service errors are covered (TC17, TC28); data consistency/integration verification covered (TC29).
Performance and load: Response time and resource utilization scenarios under normal and peak loads are present (TC25, TC26, TC27).
Regression & compatibility: Special characters and backward-compatibility regression scenarios are included (TC23, TC24).
Documentation accessibility: API docs accessibility scenario included (TC30).
gaps: Duplicate submission / idempotency: No explicit test for duplicate POST handling (e.g., repeated identical requests or idempotency-key behavior) to confirm whether duplicates are created or rejected.

Explicit 500 Internal Server Error (server/DB failure): Tests cover 502/503 but there is no scenario that simulates an internal server/database failure (HTTP 500) to validate 500 behavior and error payload.
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests that exercise API rate limits (e.g., verify 429 behavior or throttling policies under burst traffic).
Caching & response headers: No assertions for caching-related headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or explicit Content-Type / charset validation.
Authorization scopes / permission errors (403): Tests cover missing/invalid auth (TC09/TC18) but do not exercise finer-grained permission failures that should return 403.
PluginProperty negative-type tests: No negative tests for pluginProperty element types (e.g., non-string values) or malformed pluginProperty arrays.

Concurrency semantics/detailing: While concurrent requests are exercised (TC22), there are no explicit assertions about conflict resolution, ordering, duplicate prevention, or transactional guarantees under race conditions.
Error payload schema and consistency: Error response body structure (standard error schema, machine-readable fields) is not asserted consistently across error scenarios.
recommendations: Add idempotency / duplicate-submission tests: repeat the same POST (with and without an idempotency key if supported) and assert whether duplicate BlockingState objects are created or the request is deduplicated; verify returned status/body on repeated submissions.
Simulate internal server/DB failures to assert HTTP 500 handling: create tests that force database errors (or mock them) and verify 500 responses and a consistent error schema/message.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests: generate rapid bursts of requests to validate the API returns 429 or follows documented throttling behavior and that retry guidance is clear.
Validate caching and response headers: add checks for Content-Type, charset and, if applicable, Cache-Control/ETag headers (and behavior when ETag/If-None-Match headers are used).
Cover fine-grained authorization (403) scenarios: add tests for authenticated users without required permissions to ensure 403 responses and proper error messages.
Add negative tests for pluginProperty and other field types: supply pluginProperty elements with wrong types and assert 400 and clear validation messages.

Harden concurrency tests: extend TC22 to assert the final system state (no duplicated entries unless intended), ordering expectations, and transactional guarantees; add tests that confirm proper rollback on partial failures.
Assert error response schema consistently: for 4xx/5xx responses, validate a standard error format (fields, codes, messages) so clients can handle errors programmatically.

Add end-to-end persistence checks: after successful POST, perform a GET (or other read) to ensure the created BlockingState persists and is retrievable in the system and in integrated systems (strengthen TC29).
If API supports large array responses in creation, document whether pagination applies; if so, add pagination tests.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/admin/cache/accounts/{accountId} - Invalidates Caches per account level

covered: Valid Deletion: TC01 verifies successful invalidation returns 204 and empty body.
Non-Existent Resource: TC02, TC16, TC18 validate 404 behavior when accountId is not found.
Input validation / Invalid UUID: TC03 and TC12 ensure 400 is returned for malformed accountId formats.
Authentication: TC05 and TC06 cover missing and expired/invalid tokens returning 401.
Service Unavailable / Degraded State: TC07 and TC08 cover 503 handling for high load or dependent cache service failures.
Unsupported Method Handling: TC11 verifies 405 for unsupported HTTP methods (GET) on the DELETE endpoint.
Extra Query Parameters: TC09 verifies the endpoint tolerates/ignores extra query parameters and returns 204.
Security: TC14 and TC15 test SQL injection and XSS attempts via the accountId path and expect 400.
Concurrency / Performance: TC13 exercises concurrent DELETEs and includes a performance SLA (average response time expectation).
Missing Path Parameter: TC04 checks behavior when accountId is omitted (404 route not found).
Edge / Large Input: TC10 covers very large or maximum-length accountId inputs (ambiguous expectation captured).
Transient Network Recovery and Retry: TC17 validates retry behavior after temporary network failures.
Regression / Backward Compatibility: TC12 (UUID regression) and TC19 (behavior vs previous releases) are present.
Cache invalidation assertion: TC01 includes an explicit step to assert that account-level caches were invalidated.
gaps: Authorization (insufficient privileges): No scenario where an authenticated non-admin user attempts the operation and receives 403 Forbidden; role-based access control is not tested.

Verification of actual cache state: Although TC01 asserts caches are invalidated, there are no concrete checks against the cache backend (e.g., Redis/memcached keys) or follow-up requests to prove the cache was cleared end-to-end.
Error response schema and Content-Type: Tests check for presence of error messages but do not assert Content-Type: application/json nor validate a stable error schema/fields (code, type, message).

Idempotency and sequential-delete race conditions: There is no deterministic test for repeated DELETEs (same client calling twice) or a race case where one request deletes and another, slightly later, should observe 404; TC13 only asserts concurrent 204s rather than exploring conflicting outcomes.
Soft-delete semantics: If accounts can be soft-deleted, there are no tests validating how cache invalidation interacts with soft vs hard deletes.
Rate limiting / Throttling: No tests exercise rate limits (429) or throttling behavior under high request rates.
Ambiguous expected outcomes in some tests: TC10 allows 404 or 400 which makes expectations non-deterministic; tests should be precise about expected behavior according to API contract.
Response headers and caching metadata: No assertions for headers such as Content-Type, Cache-Control, ETag or other operational headers that may be required or relevant for clients.
Test isolation and cleanup: Feature lacks explicit teardown/fixture steps to guarantee idempotent test runs and avoid cross-test pollution of DB/cache state.
Error message consistency and machine-readable error codes: Tests look for free-text messages but do not assert structured error identifiers that clients could rely on.
recommendations: Add an authorization test for an authenticated non-admin user that attempts this DELETE and assert 403 Forbidden (role-based access check).
Implement concrete cache-verification tests: after DELETE, verify cache keys are removed in the cache backend or perform a follow-up query that would demonstrate stale vs invalidated behavior.

Assert response headers and schema: for error responses assert Content-Type: application/json and validate a stable error schema (fields like error code, message, timestamp) so clients can parse errors reliably.

Add idempotency and deterministic race-condition tests: (a) repeat DELETE of the same account sequentially and assert the API behavior expected by contract, (b) create a race where one request deletes and another checks for 404 to cover real-world concurrent conflict outcomes.
Clarify ambiguous expectations (TC10) and lock expected status codes in tests to match the API contract (400 vs 404).
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests that send a burst of requests and verify proper handling (429 or backoff behavior) and that the DELETE endpoint fails gracefully under extreme load.
If the product supports soft deletes, add tests to validate cache invalidation semantics for soft-deleted accounts vs fully deleted accounts.
Add assertions for response headers relevant to API clients (Content-Type, Content-Length where applicable, and any audit headers).
Introduce test setup/teardown steps (fixtures) that reset DB and cache state between scenarios to ensure repeatability and avoid flaky tests.
Improve error assertions to check structured error identifiers or codes (not only free-text) so that clients and automation can rely on stable error semantics.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/tags - Retrieve account tags

covered: Valid Request: TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05 and related scenarios exercise successful retrieval and the primary combinations of includedDeleted and audit parameters returning 200 and JSON arrays.
Empty Response: TC06 verifies behavior when an account has no tags (empty JSON array).
Path parameter validation & error responses: TC07 (404), TC08 (400) and TC20-TC23 cover non-existent accounts, invalid UUID format, partial UUIDs, empty and whitespace accountId edge cases.
Query parameter validation: TC02-TC05, TC09, and TC10 validate accepted audit values, includedDeleted behavior, invalid audit values, and handling of unknown parameters.
Authentication errors: TC12 and TC13 cover missing and invalid authentication leading to 401 responses.
Security input validation: TC14 and TC15 check for SQL injection and XSS-style inputs and expect 400 responses.
Performance & concurrency: TC16 and TC17 cover large payload handling (10,000 tags) and concurrent request behavior, including performance expectations.
Integration & resilience: TC11, TC24, and TC25 cover API unavailability, downstream service failures (503/502), and cross-system data consistency.
Regression & compatibility: TC18 and TC19 are regression/back-compat checks to ensure previously fixed behaviors and legacy client compatibility remain intact.
gaps: Pagination: No tests address pagination (page/limit, offsets) or behavior for paged results — important for large datasets.
Caching behavior: No tests verify caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or conditional GET semantics (If-None-Match -> 304).
Rate limiting/throttling: No tests exercise rate-limiting behavior or 429 responses when limits are exceeded.
Schema validation for Tag objects: Tests assert "Tag objects" are returned but do not validate Tag schema (required fields, data types, enum constraints).
Forbidden/403 scenarios: No tests for authenticated-but-unauthorized access (403) or role-based permission checks.
Content-Type and media negotiation checks: Content-Type is asserted only in TC01; other successful scenarios do not assert response headers or Accept negotiation.
Boolean parameter negative tests: No tests for malformed boolean values for includedDeleted (e.g., includedDeleted=notABool) to confirm 400 handling.
Error body consistency: Tests check error status codes but do not assert a standardized error response structure (code/message/details).

Distinction between concurrency and rate-limit failure: TC17 tests concurrent success but does not validate behavior when concurrency crosses configured throttling thresholds resulting in 429/503 etc.

Pagination-related performance/streaming: Large dataset performance is tested (10,000 tags) but there are no tests for chunked/streamed responses or server behavior when result size is extremely large.
recommendations: Add pagination tests if the API supports paging: validate page/limit parameters, boundary conditions (first/last page), out-of-range pages, and consistent ordering; if the API does not support paging, add an explicit test documenting and asserting that behavior.
Add caching tests: assert presence of Cache-Control and ETag headers; implement conditional GET tests using If-None-Match to verify 304 responses when appropriate.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests: simulate rapid request bursts to validate configured limits and expected 429 responses and Retry-After headers.
Add JSON schema assertions for Tag objects across all successful tests (required fields, types, allowed enum values for audit-related fields) to ensure payload correctness.
Introduce 403 tests for authenticated users lacking permissions (role-based access) if applicable to the system.
Assert Content-Type and other relevant headers (Content-Length, charset) in all successful responses and add Accept header negotiation tests.
Add negative tests for malformed includedDeleted and other query parameter type mismatches to ensure clear 400 responses.
Standardize and assert error response body structure for 400/401/403/404/5xx scenarios to improve client-side error handling and testability.
For very large result sets, either add pagination or streaming tests; if returning all items is intended, add tests that validate memory/response size limits and graceful degradation/failure modes.
Separate concurrency performance tests from rate-limiting tests: verify that the system both handles expected concurrent load and properly rejects/limits requests beyond configured thresholds.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/overdue - Retrieve overdue state for account

covered: Valid request handling: TC01 and TC02 validate successful retrievals returning 200, Content-Type application/json, and OverdueState JSON schema match.
No data / empty response handling: TC02 (account with no overdue state) and TC13 (empty database) exercise how missing data is reported (200 with empty state or 404 for account not found).
Error conditions: TC03, TC04, TC05 and TC06 cover 404 and 400 scenarios for not found, malformed UUID, missing accountId, and unsupported accountId patterns.
Server and dependency errors: TC09 and TC17 cover 500 and 503/504 style failures for backend or dependency problems.
Authorization basics: TC07 and TC08 cover missing and invalid authentication tokens returning 401.
Security for path parameter: TC10 and TC11 test injection and XSS attempts in the accountId path parameter.
Query parameter tolerance: TC12 verifies extra query parameters are ignored and do not affect the response.
Performance and concurrency: TC14 and TC15 exercise response time under normal load and concurrent requests.
Large payload handling: TC18 covers retrieval when overdue history is large and checks payload size constraints.
Resilience and recovery: TC19 tests transient network failure and retry behavior.
Regression and compatibility: TC16 tests leading/trailing space regression, and TC20 asserts backward compatibility and presence of required OverdueState fields.
Schema and contract validation: Multiple scenarios validate the OverdueState JSON schema and required fields.
gaps: Caching behavior: No tests assert presence or semantics of caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or conditional GET behavior (304).
Rate limiting and throttling: No tests simulate bursts, rate limits or assert 429 responses and Retry-After headers.
Authorization granularity: No tests for 403 Forbidden scenarios, expired tokens, or scope/role based access control.

Pagination: Not covered. Note: this endpoint appears to return a single resource so pagination may be not applicable; confirm and document as N A or add tests if listing behavior is introduced in future.
Content negotiation and headers: No tests for Accept header handling, 406 responses, or other response headers (Content-Length, security headers).
Error response schema: Error body shape and standardized error fields are not validated consistently (tests only check for presence of an error message).
Detailed OverdueState permutations: No exhaustive tests for different OverdueState field combinations, boundary values, or domain-specific states.
Unsupported HTTP methods: No tests asserting that POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE return 405 for this endpoint.
Security coverage beyond path param: No tests for query param injection, header based attacks, or fuzzing of auth headers.
Rate limiting behavior under concurrent load: Performance tests exist but do not assert how the system reacts when rate limits are reached (mixed with concurrency).
recommendations: Add caching tests: verify ETag, Cache-Control and Last-Modified headers; add conditional GET tests that expect 304 when appropriate.
Add rate limiting tests: simulate high request rates and assert 429 responses and presence of Retry-After when limits are exceeded.
Expand authorization tests: include expired tokens, tokens with insufficient scopes, and role based access tests that exercise 403 Forbidden behavior.
Clarify pagination applicability: if the API will never return lists for this endpoint mark pagination as not applicable in test plan; if it may, add pagination tests for large responses.
Add content negotiation tests: exercise Accept header variations and assert proper Content-Type or 406 Not Acceptable handling.
Validate error response schema: introduce assertions for structured error payloads (error code, type, message, and timestamps) so clients can reliably parse errors.
Add exhaustive OverdueState matrix tests: verify all relevant combinations and boundary conditions for OverdueState fields and numeric/time thresholds.
Add method validation tests: assert that unsupported HTTP methods return 405 with Allow header.
Broaden security tests: include query param injection, header injection, auth header fuzzing, and scanning for common vulnerabilities beyond path param.
Integrate rate limiting assertions into concurrency/performance tests so that both performance and limit enforcement are validated together.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts - Retrieve an account by external key

covered: Valid request handling: Happy-path retrieval and multiple valid parameter combinations are covered (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05, TC16, TC18, TC22, TC23).
Required-parameter and default behavior: externalKey required and default behavior (no balance/CBA/audit) validated (TC01, TC07).

Query-parameter validation and combinations: boolean and enum validation, malformed inputs, length boundaries, and extra parameter handling are exercised (TC02, TC03, TC05, TC09, TC10, TC14, TC15, TC16, TC18, TC19).
Empty/no-data handling: 404 when account is not found or DB is empty (TC06, TC17).
Authentication negative cases: missing and invalid authentication tokens return 401 (TC11, TC12).
Security checks: SQL injection and XSS attempts and malformed externalKey handling are covered (TC08, TC14, TC15).
Dependency and error-path handling: service-unavailable, inconsistent dependent data, and timeout conditions are covered (TC13, TC24, TC25) with 503/502/504 mappings.
Performance and concurrency: response-time requirements and a concurrent-request scenario are present (TC20, TC21).
Regression and backward compatibility: previously problematic keys and legacy-client scenario covered (TC22, TC23).
Content-Type positive check: at least one scenario verifies application/json is produced (TC01).
gaps: Caching and conditional GET behavior (ETag, Cache-Control, If-None-Match, 304 responses) are not tested.
Rate limiting and throttling (429 behavior, burst handling) are not covered; TC21 only asserts concurrency success, not rate-limit responses.
Full response schema and field-level assertions are missing: no JSON-schema validation of required Account fields, types, balances (currency/precision), or CBA structure.
Authorization nuance (403 Forbidden for authenticated but unauthorized users or role-based access) is not tested; only 401 cases are present.
Internal server error (500) scenarios are not explicitly tested.
Content negotiation (Accept header variations, 406 responses) and consistent Content-Type checks across success and error responses are lacking.

Parameter precedence and corner cases are not exhaustively covered (e.g., explicit accountWithBalance=false combined with accountWithBalanceAndCBA=true, explicit audit=NONE, repeated/duplicate query parameters semantics).
Duplicate/encoded-parameter behaviors and whitespace/encoding edge-cases beyond injection/XSS are not covered.

Pagination is not tested — note: for a single-resource lookup by unique externalKey pagination is likely not applicable; confirm contract. If a search/list-by-key endpoint exists, pagination tests are needed.
recommendations: Add JSON-schema / contract tests that assert the Account object shape and types (id, externalKey, name, email, currency, createdDate, etc.) and validate balance and CBA numeric precision and currency fields.
Add caching tests: validate Cache-Control and ETag headers on successful responses, and test conditional GET using If-None-Match to produce 304 Not Modified where appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests to intentionally exceed thresholds and assert 429 responses and Retry-After headers; include burst and sustained-request scenarios.
Add authorization tests for 403 Forbidden where applicable (authenticated user lacking permission or cross-account access attempts).
Simulate and assert consistent handling of 500 Internal Server Error and test the error response schema for server-side failures.
Expand Content-Type/Accept tests to verify content negotiation (Accept header) and ensure all success/error responses use consistent Content-Type and error payload structure.

Add parameter-precedence and explicit-false combination tests (e.g., accountWithBalance=false with accountWithBalanceAndCBA=true, explicit audit=NONE) and tests for duplicate query parameters to lock down server behavior.
Add more field-level and value-edge tests for balances (zero, negative, very large amounts), and verify rounding/precision behavior.
Clarify whether pagination applies to this endpoint; if the API adds listing or search semantics, add pagination (limit/offset or page) tests including large-result handling.

Integrate the above contract, caching, and rate-limit tests into CI and include automated schema validation and monitoring of performance tests (sustained load, resource usage) so regressions are caught early.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts - Create account

covered: Valid payload creation (201 + JSON body + Location header) is exercised in TC01, TC02, TC03 and TC20 (integration).
Required header handling: presence, omission and invalid type for X-Killbill-CreatedBy covered (TC01/03/TC04/TC08).
Optional headers handling: presence of X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment covered (TC02); omission exercised by TC03 and TC16.

Request body validation: malformed JSON, missing required fields, empty payload, extra unsupported fields, injection/XSS attempt and large payload boundary covered (TC05, TC06, TC07, TC12, TC15, TC11).
Duplicate submission behaviour is explored (TC13), allowing tests to detect current system policy.
Authentication and basic authorization negative case covered (unauthorized -> TC09 returning 401).
Resilience and error handling scenarios included: database unavailable/service unavailable (TC10 -> 503) and network timeout (TC14 -> 504).
Performance and concurrency: concurrent creation test exists (TC18).
Regression and integration verification exist: TC19 (regression field truncation) and TC20 (GET the Location to verify created resource).
gaps: Content-Type / Accept handling is not explicitly tested: no tests verify missing/wrong Content-Type (should be 415) or that responses set Content-Type: application/json.
Field-level validation is sparse: no explicit tests for formats (email, date, currency, numeric ranges), enums, or per-field min/max length constraints.

Response contract completeness is not asserted: presence/format of server-generated fields (accountId, createdDate, audit fields, tenantId), and exact mapping between request fields and returned Account are not fully verified beyond basic existence checks.
Internal server error (500) or unhandled exception paths are not simulated; only 503 and 504 are covered.
Authorization granularity (authenticated but unauthorized -> 403) and role/permission checks are not covered.
Rate limiting/throttling and 429 behavior are not tested; concurrency TC18 does not assert throttling policies.
Duplicate handling is ambiguous in TC13 (test accepts 201 or 409) — policy is not enforced/deterministic in tests.
Idempotency and retry behavior for repeated submissions is not tested.
Content negotiation and caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) for retrieval are not covered (relevant for TC20 GET verification).
Security / hygiene gaps: CORS, security headers, TLS enforcement and audit header propagation (confirming X-Killbill-CreatedBy recorded) are not tested.
recommendations: Add tests for Content-Type header handling: missing or wrong Content-Type should return 415 Unsupported Media Type; assert response Content-Type is application/json.
Add Accept header and content-negotiation tests (e.g., Accept: text/html or missing Accept) and assert appropriate status (or fallback) and response Content-Type.
Implement field-level validation tests for all important Account fields: invalid/edge-case email, phone, currency, date formats, numeric ranges, allowed enums, and explicit min/max length checks.

Add assertions for server-generated fields (accountId, createdDate, audit fields) in the response and verify the Location header contains the created accountId and the GET at Location returns the same data (extend TC20 to assert field equality).
Simulate and assert internal server error behavior (500) for unhandled failures and verify consistent error payloads and logging hooks.
Define and lock a duplicate-submission policy (create-vs-conflict) and update TC13 to assert deterministic behavior (e.g., expect 409 with a clear error body, or 201 + idempotency key behavior).
Add rate-limiting / throttling tests: burst of requests to assert 429 and presence of Retry-After header and ensure proper behaviour under load beyond concurrency test (TC18).
Add authorization matrix tests including 403 Forbidden for authenticated users lacking required permissions and validate audit/logging of X-Killbill headers.
Expand security tests: verify XSS/SQL injection inputs are sanitized in storage and output, test CORS and relevant security headers, and ensure TLS is enforced where applicable.
Extend performance tests to sustained load/throughput and stability tests, and add more boundary tests per-field (unicode, very long strings, min-length violations).

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/bundles/{bundleId} - Retrieve a bundle by id

covered: Valid Request: Multiple success scenarios (TC01–TC04, TC14, TC16, TC17, TC18, TC20) verify 200 responses, Content-Type header, and returned Bundle object.
Query Parameters: audit parameter (FULL, MINIMAL, NONE), omitted default behavior, unsupported value handling, and extraneous query parameters are exercised (TC01–TC05, TC10).
Empty / Not-Found Handling: Non-existent bundle and empty-database scenarios covered, returning 404 as expected (TC06, TC11).
Input Validation & Security: Malformed UUID and XSS/injection attempts are tested and return 400, with assertions to avoid script execution (TC07, TC15).
Authorization Basics: Missing and invalid authentication token behaviors are covered and return 401 (TC08, TC09).
Error & Availability: Service unavailable (503), network timeout, and transient-server-error + retry behavior are included (TC12, TC13, TC20).
Performance & Large Payloads: Large bundle data handling and a response-time expectation (< 2s) are included (TC14).
Other quality attributes: Concurrency (TC18), accessibility/readability (TC19), regression (case-sensitivity TC16), and backward-compatibility structure checks (TC17) are present.
gaps: Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for rate-limit behavior (e.g., 429 responses, Retry-After) under bursts of requests.

Caching Behavior & Conditional GET: Missing tests that assert presence and semantics of caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) and conditional GET handling (If-None-Match / 304 Not Modified).
Authorization scope / 403 Forbidden: No test for an authenticated user lacking permissions (403) or role-based access control scenarios.
Content Negotiation: No tests for Accept header negotiation or 406 Not Acceptable responses for unsupported media types.
HTTP Method Handling: No tests asserting non-GET methods return 405 Method Not Allowed for this resource.

Explicit JSON Schema & Field-Level Validation: "valid Bundle object" is asserted at a high level but there are no strict schema/field-level assertions (required fields, types, audit object structure and contents).

Sustained Load / Throughput: TC18 checks concurrency correctness but there are no stress/load tests to validate throughput, rate-limiting triggering, or long-running performance under sustained traffic.
recommendations: Add rate-limiting tests: simulate bursts and sustained request rates to validate 429 responses, Retry-After header, and service behavior under throttling.
Add caching and conditional GET tests: assert ETag and Cache-Control headers, test If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since to verify 304 Not Modified behavior and ensure ETag changes on resource update.
Add permission-scope tests (403): exercise an authenticated token without read permissions and assert 403 Forbidden where applicable.
Add content-negotiation tests: vary Accept headers and verify application/json is served; assert 406 for unsupported media types.
Add HTTP-method tests: call POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE on /1.0/kb/bundles/{bundleId} and assert 405 Method Not Allowed.

Strengthen response validation: add explicit JSON schema checks for Bundle and audit objects (required fields, types, ISO date formats, arrays) and verify audit payload structure/content for FULL vs MINIMAL.
Introduce load/stress tests: sustained high-concurrency and throughput tests to validate performance SLAs, observe rate-limit behavior, and detect slow-path regressions.

Assert header-level observability: validate presence/format of headers such as ETag, Cache-Control, Content-Length (or chunking), and request-id / correlation-id to aid debugging and caching behavior verification.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails - Retrieve an account emails

covered: Valid Request: TC01 verifies successful retrieval with status 200, application/json Content-Type, and presence of expected AccountEmail fields
Empty Response: TC02 and TC04 validate that accounts with no emails or non existent accounts return an empty JSON array with 200
Invalid accountId format: TC03 verifies that a malformed accountId returns 400
Extra Query Parameters: TC07 confirms extra parameters are ignored and do not alter results
Authorization presence: TC05 checks missing/invalid authentication returns 401 or 403 (if auth is required)
Service Unavailability: TC06 covers handling of an unavailable API returning 503
Large dataset handling: TC08 tests retrieval of 1000+ emails and includes a response time expectation
Concurrency: TC13 addresses behavior under multiple simultaneous requests
Security: TC10 and TC11 cover SQL injection and XSS attempts in the accountId path parameter
Special characters: TC12 ensures emails with unicode and special characters are returned correctly
Transient failures/resilience: TC09 addresses client retry/timeout behavior for transient network failures
Backward compatibility: TC14 checks legacy client compatibility for response format
Accessibility: TC15 covers clarity and machine readable error messages and documentation
gaps: Pagination: No tests for pagination parameters (limit/offset/page), Link headers, or partial result handling for large datasets
Rate Limiting: No tests for throttling behavior or 429 responses and Retry-After header under high request rates
Caching Behavior: No tests for ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified, or conditional GET behavior (If-None-Match -> 304)
Full Schema Validation: Tests check presence of sample fields but do not validate the complete AccountEmail schema, types, required fields, or extra unexpected fields
Authorization Scope and Access Control: TC05 covers unauthenticated access but there are no tests for authenticated users lacking permission to view an account (authorization/ACL scenarios)
Server Error Handling: No explicit tests for 500 Internal Server Error or ensuring sanitized error responses and logging behavior
Content Negotiation and Headers: No tests for Accept header variations, character encoding, or other response headers beyond Content-Type
URL Encoding and Path Edge Cases: Missing tests for encoded accountId, trailing slash behavior, missing accountId path segment, or whitespace-padded accountId values
Ordering / Deduplication: No tests verify ordering of returned emails, stable sort behavior, or duplicate entry handling
Pagination + Performance: Large dataset test exists but pagination performance and behavior under paging is not tested
recommendations: Add pagination tests covering limit/offset or page parameters, validate paging headers (Link, total count if provided), and test edge pages and empty page results
Implement rate limiting tests that simulate burst traffic to assert 429 responses, presence of Retry-After header, and graceful client behavior
Add caching tests to verify ETag and Cache-Control headers and conditional GETs (If-None-Match) returning 304 when appropriate
Introduce full JSON schema validation for AccountEmail objects (validate field types, required fields, formats and absence of sensitive fields)
Add authorization/ACL tests for authenticated users without access to the target account to ensure 403 responses where appropriate
Simulate server errors (500) to verify sanitized error messages and ensure the API does not leak internal stack traces or implementation details
Test content negotiation and response headers beyond Content-Type (Accept header handling, charset, etc.)
Add edge case tests for URL/path handling: percent-encoded accountId, trailing slash, missing accountId, and whitespace or very long accountId values
Add tests for ordering and deduplication guarantees if the API makes ordering or uniqueness promises
Combine pagination and performance testing: measure latency and throughput when fetching paged results from very large datasets and under concurrency

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/customFields/pagination - List custom fields

covered: Valid requests: default and explicit offset/limit/audit combos returning 200 and JSON array are covered (TC01, TC02, TC06).
Audit parameter permutations: FULL, MINIMAL, NONE and invalid values (including SQL-injection-like input) are tested (TC03, TC04, TC05, TC11, TC14).
Empty response: scenario for no custom fields returns an empty JSON array (TC07).
Pagination basics and boundaries: offset/limit behavior, partial inputs (only offset/only limit), large-volume retrieval and int64 boundary cases are present (TC02, TC16, TC17, TC18, TC20).
Error handling: invalid numeric parameters and invalid audit parameter producing >=400 responses are included (TC08, TC09, TC10, TC11).
Authentication and availability: missing/invalid auth token and service unavailable/timeout scenarios are covered (TC12, TC13, TC19).
Concurrency and regression: concurrent requests, regression for incorrect pagination, and backward compatibility checks are present (TC21, TC22, TC23).
Response shape and schema: tests assert JSON array shape, item counts <= limit, and schema/accessibility checks (TC01, TC24).
gaps: Rate limiting / throttling: no tests exercise burst traffic to trigger 429 or verify Retry-After behavior.
Caching behavior: no assertions for ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified, 304 Not Modified or other cache headers.
Authorization (permission-related): only authentication (401) is tested; scenarios for valid token but insufficient privileges (403) are missing.
Malformed parameter types: non-integer or non-numeric values for offset/limit (e.g., "abc", floats) are not explicitly tested.
Header and content-negotiation checks: explicit assertions for Content-Type, Accept, and related response headers are missing.
Error response schema and exact status-code assertions: tests check for an error message or >=400 but do not validate a structured error payload or exact expected status codes (e.g., 400 vs 422).
Deterministic ordering and pagination metadata: no tests verify stable ordering across pages or presence/behavior of pagination metadata (Link headers, total count) if applicable.
Performance/load: functional large-volume retrieval is present but there are no sustained load / throughput tests or metrics to validate performance under stress.
recommendations: Add rate-limiting tests: burst a client (and multiple clients) to verify server responds with 429 when limits are exceeded and includes Retry-After header; also verify graceful degradation under throttling.
Add caching tests: assert presence and semantics of Cache-Control, ETag and Last-Modified headers; test If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since to validate 304 behavior.
Add authorization tests (403): validate cases where the token is valid but lacks required permissions, and assert correct 403 response and error payload.
Add malformed-type tests for query parameters: offset and limit as strings, decimals, or other invalid formats; assert 400 and structured error response.
Assert response headers explicitly: Content-Type: application/json, Content-Length behavior, and Accept header negotiation (406 or fallback behavior if applicable).

Validate error payload schema and specific status codes: require tests to assert structured error body (fields like code, message, field) and exact HTTP status codes for specific error classes (e.g., 400 for bad input).

Add deterministic ordering and pagination-consistency tests: seed known dataset and verify page contents, ordering, and behavior when offset >= total; test for Link/next/prev headers or total-count if the API supports them.
Add performance/load tests: sustained concurrency, throughput and latency under load, and verify timeout and retry behaviors; include assertions for graceful failure modes.
Tighten audit-field assertions: for FULL/MINIMAL/NONE assert presence/absence and exact audit fields and types rather than only presence of "audit info".
Improve negative-security tests: additional injection/fuzz tests for query params and headers and assert no sensitive internals are leaked in error messages.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/invoiceItems/{invoiceItemId}/auditLogsWithHistory - Retrieve invoice item audit logs with history by id

covered: Valid request and success path: TC01 returns 200 with a JSON array; TC12 regression checks required AuditLog fields.
Empty and no-data responses: TC02 covers invoice item with no logs; TC18 covers empty database scenario resulting in 404.
Error handling and input validation: TC03 covers 404 for not found; TC04 and TC17 cover malformed and truncated UUID inputs returning 400; TC08 covers service unavailability (503).
Authentication handling: TC05 (missing token) and TC06 (invalid/expired token) cover 401 responses.
Unsupported query parameters: TC07 verifies extra unsupported query parameters are ignored and do not break the response.
Content-Type header: TC16 asserts response includes Content-Type: application/json.
Security tests: TC10 and TC11 validate handling of SQL injection and XSS payloads and ensure no sensitive data is leaked.
Performance and scalability: TC09 (large history), TC14 (concurrent requests), and TC15 (load/response time) address performance, payload size, and consistency under concurrency.
Backward compatibility: TC13 checks response compatibility when using headers from older client versions.
Resilience and regression: TC08 and TC12 cover DB failure handling and regression for missing audit log fields.
gaps: Pagination: No tests exercise pagination or related metadata/links for very large audit log sets; no verification of page size, offsets, ordering or ability to fetch subsequent pages.
Caching behavior: No tests for caching headers (ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control), conditional GETs (If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since) or 304 Not Modified behavior.
Rate limiting and throttling: No tests simulate request bursts or verify 429 responses and Retry-After header under quota limits.
Authorization scopes and permissions: Tests cover 401 but do not cover 403 cases for authenticated users lacking permission or role-based access control.

Schema and contract validation depth: Presence of required fields is asserted, but there are no strict JSON Schema-based checks for field types, timestamp formats, enums, nested history structures, or negative contract tests.
Content negotiation: No tests for Accept header variations, unsupported media types, or 406 responses.
Server error coverage: Apart from 503, there are no explicit 500/internal server error tests to verify safe, non-leaking error responses.
Edge input cases: No tests for extremely long path parameter values, leading/trailing whitespace, URL-encoded IDs, or unicode/international characters.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: create audit log volumes exceeding any implicit page size and assert pagination metadata, ordering consistency across pages, and ability to fetch next/previous pages.
Add caching tests: assert presence of ETag/Last-Modified/Cache-Control headers; verify conditional GETs return 304 when resource is unchanged and that headers update after changes.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate high-frequency and burst requests to validate 429 responses, Retry-After header, and fair handling of legitimate traffic.
Add authorization/permission tests: include scenarios for authenticated users without sufficient permissions and assert 403 responses and correct error messages.
Strengthen schema/contract tests: validate responses against the AuditLog JSON Schema (types, required fields, nested objects, timestamp formats) and include negative contract cases.
Add server error tests: simulate generic internal errors (500) and verify error payloads do not leak sensitive system information and follow API error format.
Extend input validation tests: include very long IDs, URL-encoded values, whitespace-trim behavior, and unicode characters to ensure robust validation and sanitization.
Add content negotiation tests: verify Accept header handling and that unsupported media types return appropriate status codes or default to application/json.
Make performance tests measurable and CI-friendly: define concrete SLAs for latency and throughput in TC09/TC15, automate load tests, and assert no data truncation under peak load.
Automate test data setup/teardown and document preconditions: ensure creation of invoice items with deterministic audit histories for reproducible tests and include cleanup steps.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/invoicePayments - Trigger a payment for all unpaid invoices

covered: Successful POST behavior and 204 responses for required-only and optional-parameter flows (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05, TC29).
Path parameter validation (malformed UUID) and non-existent account handling (HTTP 404) (TC08, TC09).
Header validation: X-Killbill-CreatedBy present, omitted and empty cases handled (TC01, TC10, TC16); optional headers (X-Killbill-Reason, X-Killbill-Comment) accepted (TC02).

Query-parameter validation: paymentMethodId usage and invalid formats (TC02, TC11); externalPayment boolean positive and negative cases (TC02, TC14); paymentAmount validation (negative/zero, partial, equal, greater-than-outstanding) (TC12, TC02, TC03, TC04); targetDate format validation (TC13).
Plugin property handling: multiple values, invalid types, XSS checks, and very large arrays (TC05, TC15, TC21, TC24).
Default behaviours covered: using account default payment method and paying total outstanding when optional params omitted (TC01).
No-op scenarios for accounts with no unpaid invoices or no invoices (TC06, TC07).
Duplicate-submission and retry resilience and regression tests preventing duplicate payments (TC22, TC28).
Integration & dependency error handling: payment gateway, plugin system, and database failures mapped to appropriate HTTP responses (TC18, TC27, TC19).
Security checks for SQL injection and XSS payloads (TC20, TC21).
Edge-case coverage for extremely large paymentAmount and pluginProperty arrays; handling of unexpected query parameters is present (TC23, TC24, TC25).
Performance and accessibility coverage: normal/peak response time and resource utilization stress tests, and API documentation accessibility (TC30-TC33).
gaps: Concurrency/race conditions: no explicit correctness tests for multiple simultaneous POSTs against the same account (beyond performance concurrency) to ensure no duplicate/conflicting payments or allocation races.
TargetDate semantics: tests provide/validate targetDate format but do not verify scheduling semantics (i.e., future targetDate should schedule payment rather than execute immediately).
Transactionality/atomicity: lack of tests that simulate mid-transaction failures to confirm full rollback (no partial application) and consistent DB state on failures.
Multi-currency handling: no scenarios covering accounts/invoices with different currencies or currency-mismatch behavior.
PaymentMethod ownership: missing a test where paymentMethodId is valid but not associated with the target account (belongs to another account) and verifying correct error (e.g., 400/403).
Response headers and error payload schema: tests check status codes and error messages but do not assert response headers (Content-Type, Content-Length) or standardized error JSON schema and fields.

Authorization scopes/roles: authentication failure is covered (TC17) but there are no tests for authorization/permission boundaries (e.g., authenticated user lacking rights to trigger payment on an account -> 403).
Rate limiting/throttling: no tests for API throttling (429) or behaviour under abusive request bursts.
Allocation rules for partial payments: absent checks for allocation order (oldest-first vs other), rounding and precision when applying a partial payment across multiple invoices.
Idempotency header semantics: tests cover retries but do not validate idempotency-key behavior (if supported) or server-side idempotency guarantees under concurrent retries.
Audit/logging validation: optional headers (CreatedBy/Reason/Comment) are provided in tests but not asserted to be stored in payment metadata or audit logs.
Strictness for unknown parameters: TC25 allows two possible behaviors (ignore vs strict reject) but suite does not lock down which behaviour is required in production.
recommendations: Add concurrency correctness tests: fire concurrent POSTs against the same account/invoices and assert no duplicate payments, consistent invoice allocation, and stable end-state (compare pre/post DB and payment records).
Add scheduled-payment tests for targetDate: include future-date cases that verify the payment is scheduled (and not executed) and check plugin invocation timing/notifications.
Add transactionality tests: simulate plugin or DB failure mid-processing to ensure payments are applied atomically or rolled back and partial state is not persisted (assert DB invariants).
Add multi-currency scenarios: create invoices in different currencies and validate rejection/partial handling/currency conversion rules according to business policy.
Add paymentMethod ownership tests: attempt to use a valid paymentMethodId that belongs to a different account and assert the correct error code and message (400/403).

Assert response headers and error schema: add checks for Content-Type on error responses, ensure consistent error JSON structure (error code, message, field errors) and absence of stack traces or sensitive internals.
Add authorization/permission tests: cover cases where an authenticated user lacks permission to trigger payments on the target account and assert 403 behavior.
Add rate-limiting tests: burst or scripted high-frequency requests to verify throttling, returning 429 or other configured behaviour, and validate retry/backoff guidance.
Add allocation and rounding tests for partial payment distribution across multiple invoices, including fractional amounts and edge rounding cases.

If idempotency is supported or required, add tests for Idempotency-Key headers (replay same key) and concurrency with identical keys; otherwise expand duplicate-prevention tests to cover more concurrency scenarios.
Add audit/logging assertions: verify X-Killbill-CreatedBy/Reason/Comment are persisted in payment meta and audit logs and surface in payment records where applicable.
Decide and codify strict vs permissive handling of unknown query parameters and add tests to ensure predictable behaviour in production (update TC25 to assert the chosen behavior).

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/bundles/search/{searchKey} - Search bundles

covered: Valid Request: Happy-path and typical successful searches are covered (TC01, TC02, TC05). Status 200 and JSON response is asserted.
Pagination: Core pagination behaviors are tested — offset/limit combos, offset > total, limit=0, and very large offset/limit values (TC02, TC05, TC07, TC08, TC26).

Query Parameters: A wide range of query-parameter scenarios are present — audit=FULL/MINIMAL, invalid audit value, extra unexpected parameters ignored, and combined parameters (TC03, TC04, TC05, TC12, TC18).
Authorization: Missing and invalid authentication tokens are tested (TC13, TC14) to ensure 401 handling.

Error Handling: Client and server error scenarios are covered — malformed searchKey, invalid pagination, service unavailable, unexpected server errors, and timeout (TC09, TC10, TC11, TC15, TC16, TC25).
Security: Injection attempt (SQL injection payload) is included to verify input handling and that sensitive info is not leaked (TC17).
Empty and partial data states: No-results and empty-database scenarios exist (TC06, TC23, TC24).
Performance & Concurrency: Large-volume and concurrent-request tests are present (TC19, TC20).
Search semantics: Substring matching behavior and functional correctness for searchKey are present (TC27).
Audit behaviour: Audit levels FULL and MINIMAL are individually tested to assert presence/absence of audit info (TC03, TC04).
Response format: The Content-Type application/json is asserted in at least the primary success case (TC01).
Regression/backwards compatibility: There is an explicit scenario to check previously supported parameter combinations remain consistent (TC21).
gaps: Rate Limiting: No scenarios exercise throttling or 429 Too Many Requests behavior (Retry-After header, burst handling).
Caching Behavior: No tests for ETag/Cache-Control headers or conditional GET (If-None-Match -> 304) and cache semantics.
Default Parameter Semantics: There are no explicit assertions for documented defaults (offset default = 0, limit default = 100, audit default = NONE) when parameters are omitted.
Schema Validation: Tests do not explicitly validate the Bundle object schema (required fields, types, nested objects) or response contract beyond "Bundle objects".
Non-integer / malformed query types: No tests for non-integer values for offset/limit (e.g., offset=abc, limit=1.5) or very large numeric overflows.
Authorization nuance (403): No tests for authenticated but unauthorized users (insufficient privileges) yielding 403 responses.
Path-parameter edge cases & encoding: Missing/empty path param handling, URL-encoding/special character handling for searchKey, and very long searchKey length limits are not covered.
Content negotiation: No tests for Accept header variations or behavior when the client requests non-supported media types (e.g., 406 Not Acceptable).
Error response contract: Tests do not assert a consistent error response schema (error code, type, message, safe field exposure) across 4xx/5xx cases.
recommendations: Add rate-limiting tests that flood the endpoint to validate 429 responses, Retry-After header, and recovery behavior.
Add caching tests: verify Cache-Control/ETag headers are present, exercise conditional GET (If-None-Match) to receive 304, and assert cache-related headers across responses.

Add explicit tests for default parameter behavior: call endpoint without offset/limit/audit and assert offset=0, limit<=100 (and that returned results respect the default), and audit defaults to NONE (no audit info).
Add schema/contract validation tests that assert each Bundle object contains required fields with correct types and nested structures (use a JSON schema or strict assertions).
Add negative tests for malformed query types (offset=abc, limit=1.5), extremely large numeric values, and boundary conditions to confirm 4xx validation.
Add an authorization-role test to cover authenticated but unauthorized users (expect 403) if the API supports role-based access control.

Add path-parameter encoding and boundary tests: empty searchKey (if meaningful), long searchKey, URL-encoded special characters and reserved characters to ensure proper encoding/decoding and rejection rules.
Add content-negotiation tests: send Accept headers other than application/json and assert expected behavior (406 or proper fallback), and validate Content-Type on error responses as well.
Assert error response shape across all error scenarios to ensure consistent, machine-parseable errors and safe messages (no internal stack traces).

Where applicable, classify performance tests (TC19/TC20) as load vs. functional tests and run them in an appropriate environment — ensure SLAs (e.g., response time thresholds) are asserted and measured.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/bundles - Retrieve a bundle by external key

covered: Happy path: successful retrieval (200), JSON array with matching Bundle and Content-Type application/json (TC01).
Required parameter validation: missing, empty, and non-existent externalKey handled with appropriate 400/404 responses (TC07, TC29, TC08).

includedDeleted handling: includedDeleted=true returns deleted bundles; includedDeleted=false excludes deleted bundles (TC02, TC06) and default exclusion is implicitly covered by the happy path (TC01).
audit parameter permutations: FULL, MINIMAL, NONE verified for presence/absence of audit fields (TC03, TC04, TC05).
Error conditions: Not found (404), service/database unavailability (503), and invalid parameter values (400) are tested (TC08, TC13, TC28, TC09, TC10).
Authorization: unauthenticated and insufficient-permission cases return 401 and 403 respectively (TC11, TC12).
Security tests: SQL injection and XSS payloads validated to not expose sensitive details (TC19, TC20).
Edge cases: duplicate bundles, very large number of bundles, non-ASCII keys, max/min length limits and unexpected input format are covered (TC14, TC27, TC23, TC24, TC25, TC26).
Performance and robustness: response time SLA and concurrent requests are covered (TC17, TC18).
Extra parameters ignored behaviour tested (TC15).
Response content validation: presence of required Bundle fields asserted (basic schema check) (TC30).
gaps: Pagination: No tests for pagination (page/limit/offset) or behavior when result sets are large and paginated; if the API supports pagination this is uncovered.
Rate limiting/throttling: No tests for client throttling or 429 responses; concurrency tests exist but do not exercise rate limits or throttling policies.
Caching and conditional GET: No tests for ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified headers, or conditional requests (If-None-Match/304).
Explicit default parameter verification: Defaults for includedDeleted and audit are only implicit; there is no explicit test that omitting these params yields includedDeleted=false and audit=NONE.

Detailed schema and type validation: TC30 asserts presence of required fields but there are no thorough assertions for field types, nested object shapes, numeric/date formats, or prohibited additional properties.

Error response format and headers: Error responses are not consistently checked for Content-Type application/json or adherence to a documented error schema, and tests do not assert lack of sensitive diagnostic data consistently across errors.
Generic 500 Internal Server Error handling: Tests simulate 503/service down but do not cover generic 500 responses or recovery/retry/backoff behavior.
Caching-related interactions with query params: No tests check how audit or includedDeleted parameters affect cacheability or cache keys.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: verify page/limit or offset behavior, total counts, and boundary conditions, or document that the endpoint does not support pagination to avoid ambiguity.
Implement rate-limiting tests: simulate bursts and sustained request rates to verify 429 responses and graceful degradation; include retries/backoff behavior if clients implement it.

Add caching and conditional GET tests: assert presence of ETag/Cache-Control/Last-Modified headers, test If-None-Match returning 304 when appropriate, and verify caching interactions with audit/includedDeleted parameters.
Add explicit default-parameter tests: verify that omitting includedDeleted results in excluded deleted bundles and that omitting audit returns NONE audit level.
Extend schema validation: use JSON Schema-based assertions to validate field types, nested structures, required vs optional fields, and absence of unexpected fields for Bundle objects.
Standardize error response checks: assert Content-Type, error body schema, and that error bodies do not leak stack traces or sensitive details for all 4xx/5xx scenarios.
Add tests for generic 500 Internal Server Error and recovery: simulate unexpected server errors and validate client-visible behavior and monitoring/alerts if applicable.

Isolate heavy/integration tests: move 10k-bundle and duplicate-data scenarios into an integration/performance suite with controlled setup/teardown to keep unit/integration test suites stable and fast.
Verify charset and URL-encoding behavior more explicitly: test UTF-8 encoding, percent-encoding of special characters, and header encodings to prevent encoding-related bugs.
If rate-limiting and caching are intentionally unsupported for this endpoint, document that explicitly in the story/tests to avoid false-negative coverage items.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/invoicePayments/{paymentId}/customFields - Modify custom fields to payment

covered: Valid Request: Multiple successful update scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC17) verify 204 responses and database updates.
Header enforcement: Required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy is tested (TC07) and optional headers X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment are exercised (TC02).
Path parameter validation: Invalid UUID format (TC05 -> 400) and well-formed-but-not-found UUID (TC06 -> 404) are covered.
Request body validation: Missing body (TC08), malformed JSON (TC09), and invalid CustomField objects (TC10) are covered.
Authorization: Missing/invalid authentication token returns 401 (TC11).
Server error handling: Database/unavailable dependency scenario covered (TC12 -> 500).
Security validation: Injection attempt covered (TC13) to assert input rejection.
Edge cases & limits: Very large array (TC14), very large payload size (TC20), and max-length value checks (TC15) are included.
Extra/unknown properties handling: TC16 checks handling of unexpected properties in payload.
Duplicate handling: TC18 addresses duplicate custom field names (regression scenario).
Concurrency/performance: Concurrent requests (TC19) are included to exercise race conditions / throughput.
Integration/consistency: Subsequent GET to verify persistence after update (TC17).
gaps: PUT semantics (replace vs merge): No explicit test confirms whether PUT replaces the full custom-fields collection or merges with existing fields (i.e., partial-update vs full-replace behavior).
Content-Type / Accept handling: No tests for missing/incorrect Content-Type (e.g., expect 415) or verifying response Content-Type (Produces: application/json).
Response headers & error body shape: Tests do not assert response headers (Content-Type, caching headers) or the exact structure/fields of error responses.
Authorization nuance (403): Only 401 is tested; scenarios for valid token but insufficient permissions (403 Forbidden) are missing.
Idempotency / duplicate submission: No tests verify idempotency when same PUT is sent multiple times (duplicate submissions handling).
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests for server behavior under sustained high request rates (429 or throttling behavior).
Detailed schema constraints: Lack of exhaustive tests for CustomField schema details (required properties, allowed types for each field, name format rules).
Explicit test for payload too large rejection (413): Large-payload success is covered but not explicit handling when payload exceeds server limits.

Concurrency correctness: TC19 checks concurrent requests but does not assert on lost-updates, optimistic-lock failures, or application-specific conflict resolution (last-writer-wins vs conflict response).
Behavior when body is not an array: No test for non-array payload types (e.g., JSON object, null) to ensure 400/validation error is returned.
Optional header validation: No tests for invalid/oversized X-Killbill-Reason or X-Killbill-Comment values.
recommendations: Add a clear PUT semantics test: start with pre-existing fields A,B; PUT with only A2 and assert whether B is removed or retained (explicitly document and test replace vs merge behavior).
Add Content-Type and Accept header tests: request without Content-Type or with application/xml should assert 415/400; verify response Content-Type is application/json for errors and as documented.
Add tests that validate the shape and fields of error responses (error codes, message fields) and verify Content-Type on 4xx/5xx responses.
Add authorization role/permission tests: call API with a valid token lacking required permissions and expect 403 Forbidden (role-based access).
Add idempotency/duplicate submission tests: send the same PUT twice and assert no duplicates or unintended side-effects; document intended idempotency behavior.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests: exercise burst traffic and long-run high QPS to verify 429 or backoff behavior and ensure graceful degradation.
Expand CustomField schema tests: validate required attributes, allowed value types, disallow nulls where appropriate, enforce name format rules, and verify meaningful validation errors.
Add explicit large-payload-failure tests: submit payloads exceeding server-configured limits and expect 413 Payload Too Large or graceful handling, plus resource-exhaustion monitoring.

Add stronger concurrency correctness tests: simulate conflicting concurrent updates and assert application behavior (conflict response or last-writer-wins) and verify no data corruption or lost updates.
Add tests for non-array bodies and other malformed but syntactically-valid JSON shapes (e.g., object instead of array) to ensure proper 400 validation errors.
Add tests for optional header edge-cases: very long strings, invalid characters, and empty values for X-Killbill-Reason / X-Killbill-Comment to verify header validation.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/invoicePayments/{paymentId}/customFields - Retrieve payment custom fields

covered: Valid requests and audit handling: Successful retrieval for default and explicit audit levels (NONE, FULL, MINIMAL) are covered (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC16).
Empty responses: Payments with no custom fields return HTTP 200 and an empty JSON array (TC04, TC19).
Query parameter robustness: Extra unknown query parameters are ignored and malformed audit values return HTTP 400 (TC05, TC25).

Input validation and error codes: Invalid paymentId formats and malicious inputs are handled with HTTP 400; syntactically valid but non existent UUID returns HTTP 404 (TC06, TC07, TC13, TC14, TC20, TC21).
Authorization negative paths: Missing or invalid authentication yields HTTP 401 (TC08, TC09).
Dependency and service failure handling: Service unavailable and upstream dependency failure are covered (HTTP 503, HTTP 502) (TC10, TC17).
Performance and scale basics: Large payload test (1000 custom fields), response time threshold, and concurrency are included (TC11, TC12, TC24).
Resilience and retry: Retry after transient network failure is tested (TC15).
Data consistency and regression: Newly added custom fields are returned and regression for previously failing empty-array case is covered (TC18, TC19).
Security checks: SQL injection and XSS patterns in paymentId are tested and expected to be rejected (TC13, TC14).
Edge-case input handling: Trailing spaces and various special characters are checked (TC20, TC21).
